Item_Details.Item_Response: Jake had knowledge about what to do in a situation like this. In a dangerous crisis, Jake would feel sick especially when Paul was under piles of snow because of the avalanche. In the text it describes how Jake was feeling during the avalanche. It says, "Jake felt sick. The avalanche had rolled about a quarter-mile down through a chute and into a wider bowl. Icy lumps of snow had gathered in piles where the slope flattened." Jake is also a quick thinker too because if it wasn't for his quick thinking, Paul would not have been able to get out under the piles of snow on-top of him. In the text it says, "Jake knew that trained skiers who were caught in an avalanche would try to swim atop the flow and get to the side of the avalanche field just past a rock. He thought he saw a glimmer of light and recognized it as the tip of a ski." Later Thomas says to Paul, "Dont thank us, thank your reporter buddy over here. Jake was the one who spotted your ski tip sticking out of the snow."

A conclusion that can be drawn from the text about Jake's behavior in a crisis would be that he is observant and calm and thinks carefully about what to do. When Paul fell, Jake knew that he was nervous and concerned about Paul, but tried to put these feelings behind him so he could concentrate. When he was calm, he listened to what he had to do. He followed the patrolmen and helped them to search, as he was told. When searching, Jake was very observant. If he noticed something, he did not let it pass him by. Instead, he spoke up to see if his observations made a difference, which they did. For example, he saw a glimmer of light when they were searching and immediately knew it might be a part of Paul' skis, which could help them to find Paul. So, he called the other patrolmen to come look at the light and see if it was Paul. The light was the tip of Paul's ski, and because Paul was with his skis, they were able to find Paul. These examples from the text show how Jake put his worries behind him so he could pay his full attention to what needed to be done. Therefore, I've concluded that Jake is very observant, focused, and determined in a crisis.

One conclusion that can be drawn about Jake's behavior in a crisis is that he does not give up too quickly or succumb to any negitive presures, even when events seem hopeless or too difficult. In paragraph 20, it says "jake felt sick. The avalanche had rolled about a quarter-mile down a chute and into a wider bowl... Jake followed the three patrolmen as they hurriedly skied halfway down the icy slope to the top of the avalnche debris." Even during his first day on the job, even over such a long distance, and even with the possiblity of death, Jake still did what was right and followed the patrolmen to try and help. Also in paragraphs 26, the text says "Thank your reporter buddy over here. Jake was the one who spotted your ski tip sticking out of the snow." This shows that Jake was willing to work and actually try to help in some way, even when there were three other profesionals that could have probably done better." This is what conclusion I drew about Jakes behavior in a crisis.

When the patrol team went to go look for Paul, Jake just stayed put, and used common sense to help out the team. Jake's thinks fast and smart during a time of crisis. He had to make a plan before he got stuck in the avalanche. " Jake knew that trained skiers who were caught in the avalanche would try to swim atop the flow and get to the side of the avalanche if possible. He looked to the edge of the avalanche field just past a rock. He thought he saw a glimmer of light reflecting off something. He skied toward it and recognized it as the tip of a ski." He did this so the patrolman would notice the ski and rescue him.

At first, Jake felt sick when his help was required, but then his behavior matured. He cooperarted with the team of patrolmen and saved Paul's life. Jake knew that trained skiers who were caught in an avalanche would try to swim atop the flow and get to the side of the avalanche if possible. He used this knowledge to look to the edge of the avalanche field, and skied towards what he thought was a glimmer of light reflecting off of something. Jake recognized it as the tip of a ski, and the patrolmen team arrived to help Jake get Paul out from under the snow.

I can conclude that in a crises, Jake uses his background knowledge so that he can help solve the problem. For example, rather than letting his worries get the best of him, "He looked to the edge of the avalanche field just past a rock." He took this action because he knew exactly what skiers would do when they were caught in an avalanche. They would "...try to swim atop the flow and get to the side of the avalanche if possible." Jake used this knowledge and applied it to the situation, making him able to find Paul from under the snow and rescue him from danger.

"Jake knew that trained skiers who were caught in an avalanche would try to swim atop the flow and get to the side of the avalanche if possible. Jake's behaviour in a crisis was thoughtful and urgent. First, it says that Jake used his prior knowledge of how skiers surf avalanches to find Paul, by looking to the edge. This shows how he worked efficently and fast. In conclusion, Jake's behaviour in a crisis was thoughtful and urgent.

Jake is calm and collected even in a dangerous time. For example, after Paul was swept away by the snow, he remained calm, "Jake knew that trainered skiers who were caught in an avalanche would try to swim atop the flow." Jake knew that they would find him and just thought of the logical answer of where he could be instead of over reacting and freaking out like most people would do. Additionally, when he remembered where Paul was likely to be, and "saw a glimmer of light reflected off something". He was the reason for Pauls survival.

Jake is an inexpeirienced, yet helpful person in times of a crisis. During an avalanche, Paul said, "Thanks, Jake. Im so glad you wanted to write a story about us today. You saved my life" (Merfeld 1). Even though Jake had to go through training and was only there to write a story about the AC Patrolmen, he became a big help; When Paul, a fellow AC patrolmen fell in an avalanche, Jake had helped to find him by looking for his red jacket and ski's. Saving Pauls life.

I can conclude that Jake behaves calmly and acts logically in a crisis. First, when Thomas told Jake to remain calm, Jake remained calm and did not panic. Next, Jake utilized his knowledge of skiing to figure out how to find Paul. Finally, when Jake found Paul, Jake didn't panic or just stand there like a rock. He yelled for the others and they saved Paul. Therefore, Jake behaves calmly and acts logically during a crisis.
